TMI-3012-OP-0002 and
   Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059 Plans 19, 20, 22, 25.
   In the work done area record:
   a. Any deviations from the plan.
   b. Lane closure start time.
   c. Lane closure finish time.
   d. Weather conditions.
4  Reference manuals:
    LSE Technology Pty Ltd
   S-STG-TL-1727 Specifications for UHF and Radio Rebroadcast Systems.
   M-STG-TL-1728 Equipment Manuals for UHF & Radio Rebroadcast Systems.
   M-STG-TL-1729 System manual for UHF & Radio Rebroadcast System.
   M-STG-TL-1730 Test Procedures for UHF & Radio Rebroadcast Systems.
   WARNING: THE LIGHT EMITTED FROM A FIBRE OPTIC CABLE MAY BE EITHER
VISIBLE
   OR  INVISIBLE, DIRECTING THE FIBRE OPTIC CABLE TOWARDS THE EYE OR
LOOKING
   DIRECTLY INTO THE END OF A FIBRE OPTIC CABLE WHICH IS EMITTING LIGHT
,WILL
   CAUSE IRREVERSABLE  DAMAGE TO THE EYE.
   WARNING:  PERSONAL CONTACT WITH THE RADIO FREQUENCY OUTPUT OF RADIO
  TRANSMITTERS CAN CAUSE BURNS TO THE BODY.
5.  AM/FM Transmitter Levels
   (a) Measure FM Transmitter level at the east and westbound downlink
monitor point
         (A1 and A2) on the Grant Street patch panel.  Connect the
spectrum analyser to the RF
         monitor point A1 (Burnley Tunnel), set the analyser to display
the FM carriers.  Measure
         and record the carrier level for each station on form
TMF-3012-OP-0108.
         Repeat for the Domain Tunnel at monitor point A2.
   (b) Measure and record the transmit output level for each AM
transmitter, located in TSH 08,
         on the transmitter hybrid combiner.  Connect the spectrum
analyser via suitable
         attenuation to the hybrid combiner output monitor on the
Burnley Tunnel zone.  Measure
         and record the levels  on form TMF-3012-OP-0108.
         Repeat for the Domain Tunnel zone combiner.
6.1     UHF Base Station Levels
         The system will be taken out of service to perform this check
by removing the antenna
          connection from the TX 3:1 combiner.
   (a) Measure and record the carrier levels for the UHF Base Station
Tunnel Downlink
         Transmitters.  Connect the spectrum analyser to the downlink
monitor test point (A1).
         Locally key each base station exciter by pressing the local
PTTbutton.  Measure and
         record the result for each base station on form
TMF-3012-OP-0108.
         Repeat for the second zone (A2).
   (b) Check the levels of the Off-air levels of the UHF base station.
 Disconnect the antenna
         from the 3:1 TX combiner.  Connect the spectrum analyser to
theTX 3:1 Combiner
         output via suitable attenuation.  Locally key t he base
stationexciter by pressing the PTT
         button.  Measure and record the carrier level for each base
station on form
         TMF-3012-OP-0108.
         Return the system to service by reconnecting the antenna to
theTX 3:1 combiner.   [_ _]
6.2.     Tunnel Uplink Receiver Tests.
          The operation of each base station receiver will be confirmed
by injecting a test signal
          into the uplink path and observing the operation of the
receiver carrier squelch.
    (a) Connect the IFR radio test set to the Grant Street patch panel
connector B12
          (Inject uplink).  Set the IFR carrier level to -80dBm.  Injecttest
carriers at the frequencies
          shown on form TMF-3012-OP-0108.  Observe and record that the
carrier squelch
          operates for each of the carriers on form TMF-3012-OP-0108.
 Operation of the carrier
          squelch is indicated by an orange LED on the receiver front
panel.
6.3     Off-air Receiver Tests.
          The operation of each Off-air base station receiver will be
confirmed by injecting a test
          signal into the Off-air input receive filter.  The UHF
repeater downlink will be removed
          from service during this test by disconnecting the antenna
from the RX input filter.
         The operation of the receiver can be confirmed by observing
thereceiver carrier front
         panel orange RX squelch LED.
    (a) Connect the IFR radio test set to the input RX filter and set
the IFR carrier level to
          -80dbm.
          Inject test carriers at the frequencies shown on  form
TMF-3012-OP-0108.  Record the
          result for each of the carriers.
          Return the UHF downlink to service by reconnecting the
antennato the RX input
          filter   [_ _].
6.4     Downlink RF Level Tests
          The operation of the downlink is verified by measuring the
101.1 Mhz FM station level
          at each equipment room.  Measurements are made at the
equipment downlink amplifier
          VHF monitor test point.
    (a) Connect the spectrum analyser to the monitor point.  Measure at
each equipment room
          and record the 101.1 Mhz carrier level.
6.5     Uplink RF Level Tests.
          The operation of the Uplink is verified by injecting a test
signal at each equipment and
          measuring the level at the Grant Street patch panel uplink
monitor point.
   (a)  Set the RF signal generator to 450 Mhz -20dBm Carrier
unmodulated.
          At each of the equipment rooms,  connect the RF signal
generator into either of the
          uplink combiner inputs.  Measure the level at the Grant
StreetTSH 08 patch panel
          A5 - A11 and record the result on form TMF-3012-OP-0108.
7. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal parameters
in the ""Work Done""
    area of the job sheet.  Raise a new job sheet for any works that
require further attention.
    Job priority = P1 High priority.
8. Notify the control room on completion of the inspection.

            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	       Street Portal (Sturt Street - Outside Portal) as per
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	       Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059 Plans 22, 23, 25.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	4. Request TCR to issue SIRO with an Ambulance key.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	5. At each displan box, listed on form TMF-3012-OP-0306
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   EMERGENCY DISPLAN SYSTEM, the SIRO is to:
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   (a) Visually inspect the enclosure for damage and graffiti
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   (b) Visually inspect the enclosure door, hardware and gaskets
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	       for damage.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   (c) Check the enclosure for insect infestation.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   (d) Clean the enclosure of accumulated dirt and debris.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   (e) Record the result of the visual inspections on form
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	       TMF-3012-OP-0306 - Emergency Displan System
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   (f) (i) At each telephone, in turn, dial the Translink
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           Traffic Control Room, phone number 9674 2070 and
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           confirm two way communication, with the operator
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           using the telephone. Advise the operator of the
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           number of the phone which is being used.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	      (ii) The Traffic Control Room operator is to call the SIRO
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           on the telephone number provided in 4 f(i) and once
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           again confirm two way communication between the
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           operator and the SIRO.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	    (g) The result of the test is to be recorded on Form
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	        TMF-3012-OP-0306 Emergency Displan System by indicating
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	        OK or FAIL.  Any other outstanding issues are to be
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	        recorded on the form TMF-3012-OP-0306 Emergency Displan
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	        System.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	6. Any service or operational difficulties with the emergency
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   telephone systems are to be reported to Telstra's Corporate
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   Faults on number  132 255 by the TCR.  The TCR is to
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   obtain a job number from the Telstra Operator.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	7. Notify the Traffic Control Room on completion of this work.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	8. The completed job sheet and form TMF-3012-OP-0305 is to be
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   returned to the Road Service and Traffic Manager or his
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   representative and a copy be forwarded to the Team
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   Leader - Civil or his representative.

            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	A Job Start as a minimum must be completed in consultation with
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	all participating employees to identify, assess and control the
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	hazards prior to work commencing.

            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	minimum:
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           Traffic
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           Manual Handling
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           Sharps & other foreign objects
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           Slips, Trips & Falls
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           Noise
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           UV radiation
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	           Inclement weather

            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	identified, assessed, controlled and noted on the Job Start form prior
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	to the work commencing.

            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	system in the

            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	_]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	    - W2B/E6B Church St to Domain Tunnel   [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	    - W4/E1 Southbank Interchange    [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	    - as per Work Instruction TMI-3012-OP-0009..
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	2. Keys to perimeter gates maybe required.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	3. Notify control room prior to commencing work.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	4. Use flashing amber beacon light on vehicles and wear fluorescent vestwhen
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	on foot.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	5. Clean surface drainage of any form of debris (Kerb & channel, spoon
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	drains).

000030014555	12 M Insp Cln Mezzanine area            	0000000000015559	12 M Insp Cln Mezzanine area            	A	AU02151 	01	12 M Inspect Clean Mezzanine area
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the cleaning
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	and inspections of the Building and Electrics, prior to leaving
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum Cleaner, Cloths, lamps for
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	fluorescent, emergency, Exit and external lighting, Brooms,
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	Rubbish bags, Filter material, Ladders. Industrial Vacuum
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	Cleaner to be used for the Mezzanine Level.  Hire to be arranged
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	prior to commencing the job.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	A INTRODUCTION
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	2. This Job is for the inspection and clean of the Mezzanine
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   area.   [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	3. On entering the Mezzanine area, be aware of the atmosphere,
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to monitor any
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   abnormal events.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	4. Be aware for any evidence of insect or rodent infestation.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   Record any abnormal parameter in the Work Done area of the
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   job sheet.  Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   corrective actions.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	This job is a combined job for the inspection of the electrical
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	installations and cleaning of the relevant areas.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	B ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	1. Check the lighting of the mezzanine area for operation,
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   including the operational tube within EXIT signs, replace or
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   repair any faulty lighting fixture.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	2. Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware,
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   gaskets, seals and escutcheons for serviceability and general
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   operation, lubricate as required.  Carry out any required
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   actions.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	3. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   looseness, and damage.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	4. Inspect all electrical enclosures (where appropriate)
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   internally for dust, grime and condensation, clean enclosures
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   of any accumulated dust, dirt and debris.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	5. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   obstructions.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	6. Visually inspect systems, mounted within the relevant areas
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	  (where appropriate), for faulty indicators, faulty meters,
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   damaged switches and buttons etc, carry out repairs or
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   indicator lamp replacement or raise a new job sheet for any
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   outstanding actions.   [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	7. Clean lighting diffusers (including emergency and Exit
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   lighting) and lens of accumulated dust and debris.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	8. Check and clean cable trays for accumulated debris, evidence
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   of water accumulation.  Record anything  abnormal in the Work
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   Done area of the job sheet.  Record anything abnormal in the
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   Work Done area of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader or
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   his representative of outstanding actions.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	Mezzanine Level Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	1. Check the interior walls and floors for evidence of moisture
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   ingress.  Inspect for source of any water.  Record any
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   details in the Work Done area of the job sheet and inform the
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   Team Leader or his representative.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	2. Check that the mezzanine area is not obstructed by
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   furnishings and or stored items.  Remove any
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   obstruction.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	3. Check the doors and windows for damage, operation, lubricate
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   and repair as required and record in the Work Done area of
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   the Job Sheet.  Inform the Team Leader or his representative
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   of any outstanding works.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	4. Clean and remove by vacuuming, dust and debris from tops of
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   cabinets, ledges, cable trays, cables, etc.   Note: Dust will
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   settle on all ledges and surfaces, e.g. Tops of cabinets,
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	  tops of cabinet doors,  tops of meter escutcheons etc.  [_ _].
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	5. Clean exterior surfaces of cabinets as required.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	6. Clean dust and cobwebs from interior walls, cabinets and
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   ceilings.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	7. Remove from site all accumulated rubbish and debris.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	8. Sweep and vacuum all floor surfaces.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	9. Clean hand rails (if applicable) of dust and dirt.  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	10. Remove any accumulated debris from the building surrounds
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	    (where appropriate).  [_ _]
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	11. Prior to leaving the site ensure:
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	    (a) All plant turned OFF has been returned to service
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	        e.g. Fans, Air Conditioners.  [_ _]

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
   during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995.  This
   standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
   and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
   lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
   place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
   this discharge test.   [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive end
   blackening, even when the lamps still operate.  Record on
   EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - GRANT ST MEZZANINE
   FLOOR LEVEL  TMF-3012-OP-0241, only those fittings in which
   the tubes have been replaced.
   FA - 2 x 36w tube
   FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
   FC - 1 x 18w tube
   EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
   EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
   EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
   EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
   EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
   EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
   EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
   EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
   EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
   90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
   LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - GRANT ST MEZZANINE FLOOR LEVEL
   TMF-3012-OP-0241, only those lights which does not provide
   suitable area lighting for the required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
   condition and then check that the battery charger operation
   indicator functions correctly.  Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
   DISCHARGE TEST - GRANT ST MEZZANINE FLOOR LEVEL
   TMF-3012-OP-0241, only those light fittings that the battery
   charger operation indicator does not function correctly.
8. Clean all light emitting and reflecting surfaces of the
   emergency lights and exit signs. Record any broken or damaged
   diffusers on the form EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST -
   GRANT ST MEZZANINE FLOOR LEVEL TMF-3012-OP-0241 for
   subsequent replacement.
9. Ensure the emergency lighting and exit signs operate in the
   correct relationship to the normal lighting.
10. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
    parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.

3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
   Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at  Melbourne City
   Link Tunnel Project.  M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
     vibration.   [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
     a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
        LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
        measured with a portable thermometer.  Ambient
        temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
        setting.   [_ _]
     b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
        the following steps
       (i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
           displayed)
      (ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
     (iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
           setting.
      (iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
       (v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
      (vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that temperature
           shown on unit  is consistent with new setpoint and
           verify temperature is consistent with ambient
          (+ or - 1 deg) using portable  thermometer.   [_ _]
     c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
        original setting.   [_ _]
     d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when the new
        setpoint is reached and verify that the temperature is
        consistent with ambient using the portable
        thermometer.   [_ _]
    NOTE:  LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
    cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
     and that the control room receives the alarm..   [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary. - Filter type
     Liebert size 650x590x75 mm
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
     is clear.
4.6. Restart unit and set for remote operation.
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
     operation.   [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
     running.   [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local fan isolating
     switch.   [_ _]
5.4. Inspect  for loose connections or leaking coils.   [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean condenser coils, if required using compressed air.
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local fan isolator.   [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
     Unit.   [_ _]

Please Note: The water meter, mounted on the special hydrant
connection reads in litres, with the rotation of rightmost digit
(wheel) equal to 10 litres and therefore each graduation on the
rightmost red wheel being equal to o ne litre.
e.g. with a reading, showing all twos, the reading would
represent 222,222,222 litres.

1. Ensure tunnel closure permits are arranged.

3. Set up the lane closure, as per Work Instruction, Traffic
   Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink  Procedure
   PR-RS-IR-059 Plans 25 & 26.
4. Testing of the longitudinal drains are to be carried out in
   accordance with work instruction TMI-3012-OP-0036.
   Six drainage bays with longitudinal drainage are defined in
   Drawing Nos. STG-CI-2109 and 2110.  The bays are approx. 50
   mts long.  For layout of the testing inlet and outlet pipes
   refer to TMI-3012-OP-0036.
5. For Bay 1, at the Dirty Water Pit 77 (Inlet) [Check Collector
   Pipes]
   (a) At the Clean Water Pit 243, measure the flowrate and test
       the water for pH level.  Record the results on form
       BURNLEY TUNNEL LONGITUDINAL PAVEMENT DRAIN FLUSHING
       DETAIL TMF-3012-OP-0316.    [_ _]
   (b) Remove caps from the collector pipe inlets inlet.  [_ _]
   (c) Inject water into collector pipe DC and monitor for
       response time, flowrate and quality.  [_ _]
   (d) Inject water into collector pipe CC and monitor for
       response time, flowrate and quality.  [_ _]
   (e) Inject water into collector pipe UC and monitor for
       response time, flowrate and quality.  [_ _]
       Record the results on form BURNLEY TUNNEL LONGITUDINAL
       PAVEMENT DRAIN FLUSHING DETAIL TMF-3012-OP-0316.    [_ _]
6. For Bay 1, at the Dirty Water Pit  77 (Inlet) [Check dousing
   path for integrity]
   (a) Attach the Supply hose to injection points DD1 and
       DD2.  [_ _]
   (b) Ensure pipes DC, CC & UC have caps fitted.  [_ _]
   (c) Remove caps from Outlet pipes D1 and D2 in the Clean
       water pit 243.  [_ _]
   (d) Measure flowrate as well as take a water sample and test
       the pH of the water coming from the MC pipe.  Record the
       flowrate and pH on form BURNLEY TUNNEL LONGITUDINAL
       PAVEMENT DRAIN FLUSHING DETAIL TMF-3012-OP-0316.    [_ _]
   (e) Turn on the water supply, monitor and record the response
       time taken for the water to travel from the inlet pipe
       and to appear at the MC pipe at the CW Pit.  Record the
       response time on form BURNLEY TUNNEL LONGITUDINAL
       PAVEMENT DRAIN FLUSHING DETAIL TMF-3012-OP-0316.   [_ _]
   (f )  Turn off the water supply.  [_ _]
7. Replace caps on Outlet pipes D1 and D2 at the CW pit.  [_ _]
8. At the Dirty Water Pit  (Inlet) [Check drainage path for
    integrity]
   (a) Turn ON the water supply and adjust to provide 1.2l/s at
       100kPa and inject 1000 litres into pipes DD1 and
       DD2.  [_ _]
   (b) Monitor
      (i) the start and finish water meter readings
     (ii) response time for water to flow from the outlet MC
          pipe at the Clean Water Pit.
     iii) the quantity and quality of the flow and record on
          form BURNLEY TUNNEL LONGITUDINAL PAVEMENT DRAIN
          FLUSHING DETAIL TMF-3012-OP-0316.    [_ _]
9 Repeat step 8 for Inlet pipes CD1 and CD2.
10 Repeat step 8 for Inlet pipes UD1 and UD2.
11 Replace the sealing caps on pipes DD1, DD2, CD1, CD2, UD1 &
   UD2.  [_ _]
12 Replace covers on the DW and CW Pits.  [_ _]
13 Repeat steps 4 through to 11 for Bay 2 Inlet DW 75 outlet
   CW 242.
14 Repeat steps 4 through to 11 for Bay 3 Inlet DW 73 outlet
   CW 241.
15 Repeat steps 4 through to 11 for Bay 4 Inlet DW 71 outlet
   CW 240.
16 Repeat steps 4 through to 11 for Bay 5 Inlet DW 69 outlet
   CW 239.
17 Repeat steps 4 through to 11 for Bay 6 Inlet DW 67 outlet
   CW 238.
18 Record anything outside normal parameters in the Work Done
   area of the Job Sheet.
19 Ensure the job sheet and the attached form  BURNLEY TUNNEL
   LONGITUDINAL PAVEMENT DRAIN FLUSHING DETAIL TMF-3012-OP-0316,
   both completed, are forwarded to the Civil team Leader on
   completion of the job.
20 Notify the control room on completion of the job.

A Job Start as a minimum must be completed in consultation with
all participating employees to identify, assess and control the
hazards prior to work commencing.
The job start should take into account the following hazards as a
minimum:
           Traffic
           Manual Handling
           Sharps & other foreign objects
           Slips, Trips & Falls
           Noise
           UV radiation
           Inclement weather
Other hazards particular to the location or conditions should be
identified, assessed, controlled and noted on the Job Start form prior
to the work commencing.

1. Inspect and clean the in-pavement expansion joint systems in
   the following WL 2 sectors:
   S5/N3 Tollway Flemington Road to Dynon Road
   S6/N2 Tollway Dynon Road to Footscray Road and
   S7/N1 Tollway Footscray Road to West Gate Freeway.
2. Notify control room prior to commencing work.
3. Use flashing amber beacon light on vehicles and wear
   fluorescent vest when on foot.
4. Inspect the expansion joints
   (a) for an accumulation of debris (Nuts, bolts and hard
       debris) that may cause the expansion joint to not
       function correctly
   (b) for an accumulation of debris that may cause a blockage
       and stop any waterflow.
   (c) for an accumulation of debris that is greater than 20mm
       deep that  will support
       vegetation growth.
5. Clean the expansion joint of debris and blockages that have
   built up.
6. Check the expansion joints for structural damage and loose or
   missing components including nuts, bolts and surrounds.
7. Record in the Work Done Area of the job sheet any outstanding
   on-going corrective actions and the location of the expansion
   joint.
8. Raise a job sheet for any outstanding corrective actions on
   any expansion joints.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
   during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995.  This
   standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
   and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
   lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
   place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
   this discharge test.   [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
   end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate.  Record on
   EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 3 AND ENVIRONS
   TMF-3012-OP-0245, only those fittings in which the tubes have
   been replaced.
   FA - 2 x 36w tube
   FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
   FC - 1 x 18w tube
   EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
   EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
   EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
   EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
   EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
   EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
   EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
   EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
   EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
   90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
   LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 3 AND ENVIRONS
   TMF-3012-OP-0245, only those lights which does not provide
   suitable area lighting for the required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
   condition and then check that the battery charger operation
   indicator functions correctly.  Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
   DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 3 AND ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0245,
   only those light fittings that the battery charger operation
   indicator does not function correctly.
8. Clean all light emitting and reflecting surfaces of the
   emergency lights and exit signs. Record any broken or damaged
   diffusers on the form EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST -
   SUBSTATION 3 AND ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0245 for subsequent
   replacement.
9. Ensure the emergency lighting and exit signs operate in the
   correct relationship to the normal lighting.
10. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
    parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

All work on High Voltage equipment must be carried out in
accordance with Transfield's procedure number TMI-3012-SA-0102
High Voltage Safety Work Instructions.
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. (Cast Resin Dry Type Transformers 1A, 1B, 2A,2B, 3A, 3B, 4A,
   4B, 5A & 5B)
   The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
   be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
   leader or his representative.
   (a) Examine and clean all bushings, insulators, terminals,
       cable connections, for partial discharge, ingress of
       moisture or damage.
   (b) Inspect Operation of the Winding temperature sensor.
       Carry out functional testing to ensure correct Alarming
       and trip operation via the PMCS to the Traffic Control
       Room.
   (c) Check tightness (Torque test) of all earthing and cable
       connections (MEN, Bushings and tank) and inspect for
       evidence of overheating of broken strands. Tighten
       connections where necessary.
   (d) Inspect transformer coils, core and frame, for evidence
       of corrosion, dirt, or foreign material buildup.  Clean
       coils , core and frame and treat and recoat any surface
       rust spots.
3. Record in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet, inspection
   results requiring further corrective actions.  Raise a new
   Job Sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
   Leader or his representative.  Include in the Releated Job
   field of the new and this job, the job number of the
   alternate Job.   [_ _]

   M14                  58.8Nm
   Connections of LV connectors - Connection tightening torque

1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the lane to
   service the camera..
2.  Access to this camera group is:
   (a) Access Vehicle: EWP.
   (b) Position 0 and 1.
   (c) Lane closure: LHS & RHS Lanes.
   (d) Electrical cabinet location: Tollway.
3. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction, Traffic
   Control, TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure,
   PR-RS-IR-059 Plans 1, 2, 3.
4. Reference Manual, Chubb, Operations and Maintenance Manual,
   Section 4.1 (M-MCL-TM-1511)
5. Camera Junction Box / Controller Cabinet;
   (a) Check for vandalism, damage,  corrosion, ingress of
       moisture and any insect infestation, clean if
       necessary.   [_ _]
   (b) Inspect the cabinet and check that the equipment mounted
       in the cabinet is secure. [_ _]
   (c) Check the cables and terminations for signs of
       degradation, re-terminate if necessary.
   (d) Check fibre patch leads for damage and securely fastened
       to the PT140 and the LED is green, if the LED is red
       there is no signal from the camera.
   WARNING: DO NOT LOOK DIRECTLY INTO THE END OF THE FIBRE OPTIC
   CABLE, AS DAMAGE TO EYE SIGHT CAN RESULT.  [_ _]
   (e) Check that the surge suppressor red LED (on the GPO) is
       lit, if not record the fact, for later
       replacement.  [_ _]
   (f) Check with TCRO  that picture vision is OK.  If not check
       the signal from the camera using the WFM  90 meter.
      (Connect the WFM90 directly  to the lead from the camera)
   .  Ensure the co-axial cable is reconnected to the PT140
      module and is secure.  [_ _]
6. Isolate the 240V power supply to the camera heaters.
7. Camera and Camera Housing;
   (a) Check  for vandalism, damage, corrosion, external
       evidence of moisture and any insect infestation.  Surface
       insect spray  may be applied if necessary to the housing
       exterior but must not be applied to the interior of the
       housing or to the housing glass.
       If there is evidence of insect infestation or moisture,
       then open camera housing and carry out steps 7. (d) and
      (e)  [_ _]
   (b) Check that the camera housing is firmly secured to pole
       mounts.   [_ _]
   (c) Clean the glass of the environmental enclosure with
       Rain-X  cleaning fluid.  [_ _]
   (d) Check that the camera heaters are operational, ie warm.
  WARNING: HEATERS ARE HOT AND DUE CARE SHOULD BE TAKEN.  [_ _].
   (e) Discard the previously used Silica Jell pack and replace
       with a new uncontaminated Silica Jell pack.
8. Re-instate the 240V power supply to the camera
   heaters.  [_ _]
9. Check with the control centre that the AID camera is
   functioning correctly and that the MASK is aligned.   [_ _]
10. On completion of job record anything outside normal
    parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion.

   When carrying out the cleaning of VDC sensors (in 0301),
        inspect the area around the connectors for evidence of
          corrosion.
   If corrosion is evident, then clean the area as described
   below.
   Where cleaning is to be also carried out, use extreme care
   to ensure any greases or sprays do not enter any
   connectors.
   The Fibre Optic Connector is to be only removed on the
   12 Monthly  Cycle (Do not damage fibre optic cable).
   Prior to removing any connector or cover socket, clean
   surface corrosion and deposits from around connectors,
   socket covers and the surrounding surfaces use a tooth
   brush to assist if necessary.
   Remove the three socket covers (remove only if possible
   using fingers) and apply a light spray of silicon to
   the three (3) socket covers, replacing and exercising
   the threads.
   With all caps and plugs re-installed apply a light spray of
   silicon to the area around the plugs and caps.
   Check for silicon overspray on the VDC sensor window and
   clean if necessary.
   Where connectors or socket covers cannot be easily removed,
   record details in the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet and
     report the fact to the Team Leader or his representative.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

   Involve the Transfield Maintenance Staff  in the UPS Switching to
maintain UPS switching
   knowledge and awareness.
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work
2. The Galaxy UPS system 12 monthly inspection shall be carried out by
the sub-contractor in
    the presence of the electrical / electronic technician.
3. Refer to MGE UPS Systems Manual, Galaxy User Manual E-6739380XT/FA,
   M-STG-EL-24009, and Schnieder Electric Tunnel Electrical Services
Training Notes,
   M-STG-EL-24001, Section 9.
4. Record measurments on form 12 M MGE Uninterruptible Power Supply
Inspection and Test
   TMF-3012-OP-0200.
5. Check all the indicators on the hidden control panel.  Record any
alarm conditions in
   the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet and raise a Job sheet to havethe
alarm condition
   attended to.  [_ _]
6. Inspect the UPS and the batteries cleanliness, cracks, corrosion etc.
[_ _]
7. Measure and record the DC voltage of each battery. (Use Maintenance
application)
8. Measure and record (Use Maintenance application)
      UPS input voltage
      UPS output voltage
      Battery voltage
      Check the balance of each output phase and ensure the UPS is not
overloaded.
      Check for correct UPS calibration. Maintenance Program required.
      Peak and RMS loading.
      Output current and voltage wave shapes.
      AC capacitor current balance.
9. Isolate the UPS by switching to Maintenance Bypass.  [_ _]
10. Measure and record the temperature of the AC and DC filter
capacitors.  [_ _]
11. Measure and record the current flowing in various branches of the
battery circuits.  Ensure
      each path is providing an equal or representitive portion of the
load.
12. Using an optical thermometer, measure the temperature of current
carrying connections,
      during or following a current carrying period.  Terminals or
connections found with a
      temperature which is greater than ""room  temperature plus 5
degrees) should be
      investigated.  Repair any connections found to be faulty and
record in the Work Done area
      of the Job Sheet any repairs carried out..   [_ _]
13. Open the Battery Circuit Breaker and using a DC voltmeter, measure
the leakage
      voltage between battery terminal positive and earth then between
battery terminal negative
      and earth to ensure that there is no electrical leakage from the
batteries to earth.
    THE BATTERY BANK IS ENERGISED EVEN WHEN THE RECTIFIER / CHARGER AND
     INVERTER HAVE BEEN STOPPED AND THE BATTERY CIRCUIT BREAKER OPENED.
     BATTERY MAINTENANCE SHOULD BE PERFORMED BY QUALIFIED TRADESPERSONS
     IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE SAFETY REGULATIONS.  INSULATED TOOLS,
     GLOVES AND SAFETY GLASSES SHOULD BE USED.   WITH THE BATTERY
CIRCUIT
     BREAKER CLOSED, THE BATTERY TERMINALS HAVE A RELATIONSHIP TO EARTH.
14. Measure and record the string DC voltages.  If the voltage differs
by  5% from the
      expected voltage, carry out a discharge / cycling test.
15. Visually check the UPS circuit boards and components for conditions
that will lead to
      failure of the UPS.
      e.g. Security of PCB's and Ribbon cables
            Cables and connections
            Capacitors (Premature swelling, leakage)
            Evidence of overheating.
            Fuses are secured
            General cleanliness of the UPS.
    Replace or correct any fault found,  Record in the Work Done Area
ofthe Job Sheet any
    repairs carried out
16. Return the UPS to normal operation.  FOLLOW THE CORRECT SWITCHING
SEQUENCE.
17. Check the UPS readout and program software for correct operation.
(Using Maintenance
      application)
18. Simulate a power failure, Open Mains 1 Isolator (Q1), the UPS
operation will change to
      the batteries.
19. Measure and record (Using Maintenance application) the battery
voltage, at 5 sec
      intervals, for a 15 minute period.  Plot results to obtain a
Discharge Characteristics Curve.
      Compare curve with previous curves for evidence of battery
failure.  Record in the
      Work Done Area of the Job Sheet any descrepancies and raise a Job
sheet for the
      descrepancy to be attended to.  [_ _]
20.  Return the UPS system to its normal operational state.  [_ _]
21.  Notify the control room on completion of the job.  [_ _]"

   Location Details" TMF-3012-OP-0356 for the location of the
   various components and structural items for inspection.
Item 3.1
(a) Visually inspect, from the access door, the base and
    interior of each stick looking for water pooling in the
    base, evidence of moisture and or corrosion.
(b) Visually inspect the seal of the access door for damage
(c) Examine stick interior for evidence of the source of any
    possible leak e.g. Top cover or access door.
(d) Estimate the depth and quantity of any water residue and
    record.
(d) Record details of any water residues (along with source),
    corrosion and or damage on form "ANNUAL SOUTH STICK
    INSPECTION" TMF-3012-OP-0353.  Raise a new jobsheet for any
    outstanding works.
Item 3.2
(a) Visually inspect, from the ground and using binoculars, all
    faces of each stick, examining the protective coating for
    cracks, peeling, blisters and evidence of corrosion.
(b) Record details of any degradation of protective coating and
    or corrosion on form"ANNUAL SOUTH STICK INSPECTION"
    TMF-3012-OP-0353.  Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
    works.
Item 3.3
(a) Visually inspect the Foundation to Stick seal.  Examine for
    the effectiveness of the elastic seal between the steelwork
    and the concrete foundation.  Seal may separate from the
    surfaces or may be missing.
(b) Record details of any degradation of the seal material and
    or any damaged or missing material on form "ANNUAL SOUTH
    STICK INSPECTION" TMF-3012-OP-0353.  Raise a new jobsheet
    for any outstanding works.
Item 3.4
(a) Visually examine each stick for signs of structural damage.
    This would include vandalism, impact and or displacement.
    Examine the linearity of each stick against the remainder of
    the group.
(b) Inspect the access door, at the base, for damage and a full
    complement of setscrews.
(c) Record details of any structural damage along with all other
    visible damage on form"ANNUAL SOUTH STICK INSPECTION"
    TMF-3012-OP-0353.  Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
    works.

       CARRIED OUT IN ANY CHAMBER OF THE VENT STATION
3.    TAKE HEED OF NOTICES ON THE AIRLOCK DOORS.
1. Obtain a Permit to Work for entry to substation 2,  the Swan Street
ventilation rooms and to
    interrupt operations.
2.  Inform the control room prior to commencing work.   Maintain radio
contact at all times.
3.  Reference manual:  ABB Installation, Operating & Maintenance
Instructions Manual
    (M-STG-VE-26058)
4. Carry out the monthly checks on the PMCS in the Traffic Control Room.
5. Access to the ventilation fan is via ladders in the Swan Street Shaftlift
well and Substation 2
    is accessed from Swan Street.
6.(a) On the MCC in Substation No 2,  select ONE axial fan to be
operational while
         the maintenance is being carried out  on other fans.  Switch
the nominated
         AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch to the MANUAL position and the
REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
         selector switch to the REMOTE postion, then press the START
pushbutton.
   (b) Switch ALL non-operational axial fans OFF, by switching the
AUTO/OFF/MAN selector
         switches to the OFF position.  All electrical isolation
procedures are to be in
         accordance to Work Instruction TMI -3012-SA -0103,  Low
VoltageIsolation Procedures.
7. In Substation No 2
   (a) Measure the insulation resistance of the motor stator windings
and record in the ""Work
         Done"" section of the Job Sheet.   [_ _]
   (b) Measure the current of the anti-condensation heater and compare
with the rated current.
   (c) Inspect the motor control panel both internally and externally
for damage, corrosion,
         evidence of overheating,  ingress of moisture, dust and grime
(clean or repair if required).
8. (a) The fan rooms which are on levels 4, 5 & 6 are accessed from the
         Note: HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN WHEN IN ANY
VENTILATION
                     FAN CHAMBER.
    (b) Measure the CO levels in the fan rooms, through the doorway,
prior to entering the fan
          room, then at regular intervals during the fan checks.
    (c)  WARNING:  DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF THE BODY OR MATERIALS WITHIN
                                1 METRE OF AN OPERATING FAN INLET GUARD.
                                 Airflow velocity nears 35 km/h.
9. Static Fan Check.
    (a) Ensure that the fan selected for maintenance is electrically
isolated,  press the START
          pushbutton on the local push button station at Level 5.  The
fan should not start.
    (b) On level 5 open fan blade inspection hatch.
    (c) Examine the impeller for
          (i) Dirt and foreign matter on the blades (clean if required)
  [_ _]
          (ii) Wear or damage on the blade tips   [_ _]
          (ii) Wear or damage on the blade leading edges   [_ _]
          (iv) Loose bolts and or blade fixings at the hub   [_ _]
    (d) Examine the electrical cable for security of fixings, damage dueto
fraying, scuffing or
          similar and for damage at locations where the cables
penetratepanels or
          housings.    [_ _]
    (e) Check any grease discharged from the motor bearings, since the
last lubrication is not
           excessive.   [_ _]
    (f ) Examine the discharged grease for any noticable colour change.
 Ensure that the grease
          nipples are clean.  [_ _]
    (g)  Inspect the cable connections to the motor for evidence of
overheating.  [_ _]
    (h) Carry out an insulation/resistance test of the motor and heater
windings.
          (i) Ensure fan motor is isolated.
          (ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
               Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has been
isolated and is to remain
               isolated.
               (a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and
                     bridge heater terminals.
               (b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
         (iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the
motorwindings and the
                winding heater bridge.  Record the result in the ""Work
Done"" area.
         (iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out
               an Insulation resistance test between this common bridge
and earth.  Record
               the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
        (v) Remove all temporary connections.
        (vi) Remove supply lines to the motor and carry out an
insulation resistance test
              on the motor windings, Between phase winding to phase
winding and between
              each phase winding and earth.  Record results in the Work
Done area of the
             Job sheet.
        (vii) If the heater was connected on arrival, then re-instate
the heater connections,
              otherwise leave the motor winding heater terminations
isolated.
        (viii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
        (x)  Where any insulation resistance reading is less than 2
megohm, then Record
                 in the ""Work Done""area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new job for the outstanding
                 works.  Include the Job Number of the new job in the
Related Job"" field as well
                 as in the alternate.  Notify the Team Leader or his
representative of any
                 outstanding works.
    (i) On leaving the fan inlet cowl grill hatch, replace the hatch
cover immediately.  [_ _]
    (j)  Manually check the operation of the Rotork actuator and
associated linkages that
          operate the exit dampers, use the local control panel switch.
    (k ) Remove any mechanical interlocks blocking the fan operation.
 [_ _]
10. Running Fan Check and Lubrication
    CAUTION:  ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED
                         AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.
     (a) When the Static Fan Checks are complete, return to substation
3and remove the
           safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103, then removethe
fan motor isolation
           at the MCC.
           Note:  Ensure that all non-operational fans are isolated, in
accordance
                      TMI-3012-SA-0103, and that the only fan not
isolated, is the fan to be maintained.
     (b) Switch the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch from the OFF position
to the MANUAL
           position, then switch the REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switch
from the REMOTE
           position to the LOCAL position.
     (c) Return to the ventilation room and start the fan, that is
beingmaintained, by releasing
           the Local STOP pushbutton, then pressing the START
pushbutton.
           Note: The motor must not be started more that four times in
an hour.
     (d) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan starts.
     (e) Lubricate the motor bearings with fresh grease, while the motor
running.
           DE = 100 gr / NDE - 120 gr  Use Shell Stamina RL2 grease or
equivalent only.
     (f ) Remove the old grease, that was discharged from the bearings
using the retrieval
           system.  Examine the grease for changes of colour.  [_ _]
     (g) Monitor the fan and motor for abnormal noises.      [_ _]
     (h) Stop the fan motor using Local EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
     (i)  Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
11. On completion, collect all materials and leave the fan room after
equalizing the
       differential pressures.
12. In Substation No 2
      (a) Remove all safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103,
 then remove the
            motor isolation for all the fans at the MCC.  Return all
theREMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
            selector switches to the REMOTE position,  and the
 AUTO/OFF/MAN  fan selector
            switches to the AUTO position.
      (b) Check that one fan is operational and no alarms are present
13. Record anything outside normal parameters in the 'Work Done' sectionof
the Job Sheet.
14. Notify the control room on the completion of the job.
EMERGENCY OPERATION
In the event of notification by TCR Operators that a tunnel incident
hasoccured requiring the
use of fans for smoke extraction.
1. Immediately leave the fan chambers on Level 4 and Level 6 and ensure
the doors to the lift
   shaft are secured.
2. Notify TCR Operator when Level 4 and level 6 have been evacuated so
that smoke
   extraction can commence.
3. If  the fan being checked is running, advise TCR that it is
currentlyrunning under LOCAL
   control and will be returned to AUTO control.  Stop  the fan using
the Emergency STOP
   pushbutton on Level 5.
4. Release the STOP pushbutton and leave Level 5 ensuring that the door
to the lift shaft is
    secured
5. If the fan is isolated or not running, vacate all fan chambers
immediately and secure doors.
6. Notify TCR when all personnel have left the fan chambers, the doors
secured and all the
   personnel are accounted for and in the lift shaft.
7. Only if a fan was running and operational - In Substation 2  switch
the
    REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switch to the REMOTE position, as well
switch the
    AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch to the AUTO position.
8. Stop the operational fan then return the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector
switchto the AUTO
   position and restart the fan.
9. Notify TCR Operators that they have control.

1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
   shelter.
3. Check the operating condition of the Uninterruptible Power
   Supply  to ensure it is operating in the normal
   standby-back-up mode.  [_ _]
   DO NOT CARRY OUT THE GENERATOR TEST IF THE UPS IS IN BYPASS
   MODE.
4. General inspection. Reference: Cummins Onan Operator's Manual
   960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012]
   (a) Check that the generator was left in  "" AUTO ""  [_ _]
   (b) Check for any leaks of oils, fuels and water.  [_ _]
   (c) Check oil level.  [_ _]
   (d) Check battery electrolyte is above the plates.  [_ _]
   (e) Check engine block heaters ( engine is warm ).  [_ _]
   (f) Check battery voltage on Battery Charger Meter is
       between 12.5 and 13.5 Volts  [_  _]
   (g) Record the battery voltage in the Work Done area of the
       job sheet.  [_ _]
   (h) Check coolant level & fuel level in generator tank.
       Physically open the cap,as gauge could be
       misleading.  [_ _]
   (j) Fill in the Generator Log Book, compare engine hours
       with the last entry.  [_ _]
5. Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP Electrical Pty Ltd
   Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI [M-MCL-ME-20016]
   (a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
   (b) Turn the RUN / OFF / AUTO Switch on the generator DC
       panel to RUN let the engine run for at least 5 minutes,
       then turn the RUN / OFF / AUTO Switch back to AUTO
   (c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
       from AUTOMATIC CONTROL to EMERGENCY SUPPLY & TEST run the
       generator for 10 minutes.
   (d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared, and
       that there are no unusual noises or vibrations. [_ _]
   (e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
       water temperature. [_ _]
   (f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard back to
       AUTOMATIC CONTROL, the generator will continune to run
       for about 8 minutes before stopping. [_ _]
6.  Record the hours run for the generator (from the hour run
    meter) and update the Plant Usage in Mainpac from Plant
    RHMouse click select Open then Meter Readings in edit mode
    add Usage   [_________hrs].
7. (a) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
       any unusual noises.  [_ _]
   (b) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
       general operation, any oil deposits from refrigerant
       leakages  [_ _]
   (c) Report any abnormalities in the Work Done area of the
       job sheet, inform the Team Leader and/or raise a
       corrective job sheet.  [_ _]
8. Fill in the Generator Log Book  and record anything outside
   normal parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
   Raise a new job for any works requiring further repairs.
   Priority High P1.
9. Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
10. Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.

4. Inspect the fire doors listed on:
   TMF-3012-OP-0280 Substation 1 and Mezzanine level fire doors
   TMF-3012-OP-0281 Substation 2, Swan St Shaft and Refuge 3
   fire doors
   TMF-3012-OP-0282 Substation 3 & Burnley Fan Chamber fire
   doors
   TMF-3012-OP-0283 Substation 4 & Yarra Crossing fire doors
   TMF-3012-OP-0284 Substation 5, ERW 01 & Olympic Park Pump
   Station
   TMF-3012-OP-0285 Burnley Tunnel Fire Doors
   TMF-3012-OP-0286 Domain Tunnel Fire Doors
   to AS 1851.7 Type 1 inspection.  The inspection shall consist
   of an examination of the condition of the doorset and a check
   that it is operating satisfactorily.
   In particular, the following routine should be followed for
   hinged fire doors.
5.1 Inspect for any remedial work that is outstanding and
    unfinished and record works to be completed in the comments
    field.
5.2 Remove any obstructions or non-approved devices such as
    wedges, heavy objects or hooks that are used to hold the
    door open.
5.3 Check that the door and all it's components, hardware and
    functions are correct.
5.4 While the door is open, check that all screws are firm in
    the hinges, latchset faceplate, striking plate and door
    closer body and bracket.
5.5 Inspect the door identification data notice, required by the
    regulatory authority is firmly attached.  The notice is
    mounted in the door edge and on the door frame.
5.6 Check the closing and latching action (on the closing), and
    that the door stopping action (fully open limit) is
    functioning (on the opening).
5.7 The door having closed, check that the leaf is a reasonably
    even fit in the frame.

For sliding or doors that are suspended on rollers.
6.1 Inspect for any remedial work that is outstanding and
    unfinished and record works to be completed in the comments
    field.
6.2 Remove any obstructions or non-approved devices such as
    wedges, heavy objects or hooks that are used to hold the
    door open.
6.3 Check that the door and all it's components, hardware and
    functions are correct.
6.4 With the door in both the open and closed position, check
    that all screws are firm in the supports, handles, brackets,
    rollers, runners, guides and counterweights.
6.5 Inspect the door identification data notice, required by the
    regulatory authority is firmly attached.  The notice is
    mounted in the door edge and on the door frame.
6.6 Check the closing and latching action (on the closing), and
    that the door stopping action is functioning.
6.7 With the door closed, check that the door is a reasonably
    even fit over the opening.
7. Record the inspection results and the sub-contractors Work
   Report No. for each fire door on the appropriate inspection
   forms:
   TMF-3012-OP-0280 Substation 1 and Mezzanine level fire doors

   fire doors
   TMF-3012-OP-0282 Substation 3 & Burnley Fan Chamber fire

   Station
   TMF-3012-OP-0285 Burnley Tunnel Fire Doors
   TMF-3012-OP-0286 Domain Tunnel Fire Doors

   Job Sheet.  Raise a new job sheet for any corrective action
   that is required.   P2 - Medium Priority.

1. Notify the control room prior to entering each Technical
   Shelter.
2. Three Month Service Plan Reference :  Fenton Users
   Manual - Uninterruptible Power Supplies""  On-Line Series
   UME V. 5.2 4kVA, 6kVA, 8kVA, 10kVA.
3. Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
   charged ) record results in the in the UPS Battery
   Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037.  [_ _]
   [ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 13.5
    and 13.6 volts:  A voltage above 13.8 volts will
    indicate a battery fault. ]
4. (a) Press the ""Control"" button on the UPS, followed by the
   "Down Arrow"" button until the message  CONTROL BYPASS MODE
   appears.
   (b) Press the "Control" button and "Enter" button
       simultaneously, the UPS will transfer into the bypass
       mode.
,,   **If at anytime during load transfer the UPS ,,,,,,
          malfunctions, notify TCR prior to continuing.**
    c) Check the front LCD panel for any alarm conditions.  The
       "Bypass O/P" indicator should be illuminated.   [_ _]
    (d) Contact the Traffic Control Room to confirm receipt of
        alarm condition.   [_ _]
    (e) Scroll through menu using the "Display" button followed
        by the "Down Arrow"
    (f) Remove side covers from the UPS.   WARNING THE UPS IS
        STILL ALIVE.
    (g) Visually inspect the interior of the UPS for accumulated
        dust, connections or other components that may show
        obvious distress.   [_ _]
    (h) Check that both the front and rear fans are operating
       (The front fan is thermostatically controlled).    [_ _]
    (i) Press the "Control" button, then press the "Down Arrow"
        until the message "CONTROL INVERTOR MODE" appears. [_ _]
     (j) Press the "Control" button and the "Enter" button
         simultaneously, wait approx 10 seconds  until the UPS
         reverts back to its normal operation.   [_ _]
5. (a) Contact TCR prior to isolating.
,,   Switch to the OFF position the wall mounted isolator or
       CB1, on the rear  of the UPS to transfer the load to the
       batteries. Check with TCR once load has been transferred
        to batteries that a power failure has not occurred.
,,   **Do not turn isolator back on for 20 seconds as this may
        cause damage to the equipment.**
   NOTE: Ensure that the Circuit breaker (C/B2) on the rear of
         the UPS is not accidentally turned off at  this stage
         as CB2 isolates the batteries.
   (b) Continue with the UPS supplying the load from the
       batteries for at least 10 minutes.
   (c) Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
       discharged ) record results in the in the UPS Battery
       Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037.  [_ _]
      [ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 13.5
        and 13.6 volts:  A voltage above 13.8 volts will
        indicate a battery fault. ]
   (d) Check the front LCD panel for any alarm conditions.  The
     "On Battery " indicator should be illuminated.    [_ _]
   (e) Scroll through menu using the "Display" button followed
       by the "Down Arrow".  Record the voltage and current
       details on form UPS Battery Test Sheet
       TMF-3012-OP-0037   [_ _].
   (f) Switch to the ON position the wall mounted isolator or
       CB1, on the rear  of the UPS to transfer the load to the
       normal supply.
6. Battery Panel.
   (a) Wear Safety Glasses when carrying out measurements on the
       Batteries.
   (b) Ensure the Circuit Breaker operating handle, on side
       panel door, is in the upright position and is not
       tripped.  [_ _]
   (c) Measure and record the overall charge voltage across the
       CB ( nominally 217V. )    [_ _]
7. Record any result outside normal parameters, in the " Work
   Done " area of the job sheet.
8. Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
9. Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.
