**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the cleaning
and inspections of the Building and Electrics, prior to leaving
the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum Cleaner, Cloths, lamps for
fluorescent, emergency, Exit and external lighting, Brooms,
Rubbish bags, Filter material, Ladders
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. On accessing the relevant area, be aware of the atmosphere,
   use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to monitor any
   abnormal events.  [_ _]
3. Be aware for any evidence of insect or rodent infestation.
   Record any abnormal parameter in the Work Done area of
   the job sheet.   Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
   corrective actions.  [_ _]
4. Reference Manual TOJV Pump Station Operation and Maintenance
   Manuals - M-STG-ME-20001. Volume 3.
   WARNING:  BOTH THE WET WELL AND THE VALVE PIT ARE DESIGNATED
   CONFINED SPACES AND  MUST ONLY BE ENTERED UNDER CONFINED
   SPACE CONDITIONS.
   Refer to Work Instruction, Confined Space Entry
   TMI-3012-SA-0015.
5. At the Local Control Panel
   (a) Check the switchboard, situated adjacent to the pump well
       for local alarm conditions.   [_ _]
   (b) Carry out visual inspections both internally and
       externally of the control panel for damage, corrosion,
       evidence of insect infestation, ingress of moisture, dust
       and grime (clean as required).   [_ _]
   (c) Check cable connections for tightness and signs of
       overheating and inspect electrical control
       equipment.   [_ _]
   (d) Record readings of the hour run meters, for each pump, in
       the Work Done area of the job sheet.
6. Inspect the pump wet well and the valve pit.
   Remove the gatic covers from both the wet well and the valve
   pit, enter the well and inspect for general cleanliness and
   accumulated debris in the wet well, valve pit and the
   condition of the pipework and valves and any evidence of
   corrosion.   [_ _]
7. Switch the pump  PSSBP1 AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to
   the MANUAL position.   [_ _]
   (a) Measure the operating current and compare with the rated
       current. ( 170A).  Record the results in the Work Done
       area of the job sheet.  [_ _]
   (b) Check the cabling to the pump for damage and that it is
       clear from possible damage.  [_ _]
   CAUTION:  Do not pump the wet well below the Low/Low level
   alarm point as the lack of submergence may cause damage to
   the pumpset.
8. Start the pump PSSBP1 by pressing the START button.
   (a) Record the operating current of the pump in the Work
       Done area of the job sheet.  (FLC 170A.).
   (b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running, vibration
       and abnormal noises.
   (c) Observe the level controller readout for variations, with
       respect to the pump operations.    [_  _]
   (d) Stop the pump by pressing the STOP pushbutton.  Check the
       operation of each non-return valve (NRV), as the water
       flow stops.  The NRV should close with an sharp audible
       metallic sound, as well, backflow through the pump should
       cease within 30 seconds. If a faulty closure is
       suspected, the pump should be re-started,  operated
       for 2 minutes and the operation of the NRV should then be
       monitored again.    [_ _]
9. Repeat steps 7 and 8 for PSSBP2.
10. Repeat steps 7 and 8 for PSSBP3.
11. Return the AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the AUTO
    position.   [_ _]
12. Check the operation of the float switches, by removing
    circular plate in the wet well roof, then manually trip the
    floats by lifting up the High/High float and Low/Low float
    respectively with a hook bar and checking that the alarms
    are received at the Control Room.    [_ _]
13. When this job falls in either January, February or March.
    Lift the level controller sensor out of the protective
    conduit, then carefully, clean the recess in the sensor base
    of all dirt and debris.   [_ _]
14. Check the operation of each of the isolating valves, in
    turn,  by partially closing then fully opening
    again.    [_ _]
ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
1. Check the interior and external lighting for operation,
   including the operational tube within EXIT signs, replace or
   repair any faulty lighting fixture.  [_ _]
2. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all
   accessible equipment and components within all switchboards
   and distribution panels.
   Use an Infra-red temperature sensor.  Temperatures of ambient
   plus 10C should be considered abnormal and must be noted in
   the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and ensure the Team
   Leader or his representative is informed of the
   abnormality.  [_ _]
3. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
   equipment and components for evidence of burn marks, unusual
   odours and overheating.  record anything abnormal in the
   Work Done area of the Job Sheet and ensure the Team
   Leader or his representative is informed of the
   abnormality.  [_ _]
4. While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
   contactors for chattering, arcing etc.  [_ _]
5. Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware,
   gaskets, seals and escutcheons for serviceability and general
   operation, lubricate as required.  Carry out any required
   repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
   actions.  [_ _]
6. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
   looseness, and damage.  [_ _]
7. Inspect all electrical enclosures internally for dust, grime
   and condensation, clean enclosures of any accumulated dust,
   dirt and debris.  [_ _]
8. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of
   obstructions.  [_ _]
9. Visually inspect systems, mounted within the building or
   room(s), for faulty indicators, faulty meters, damaged
   switches and buttons etc, carry out repairs or indicator lamp
   replacement or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding
   actions.   [_ _]
10. PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following.
   (a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators.  Indicators
       found to indicate abnormal conditions are to be logged in
       the work done area of the job sheet and a new job sheet
       raised to investigate and correct the error.  [_ _]
   (b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
       connections, screw connections, for security.  [_ _]
   (c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and
       module security screws are not loose.  [_ _]
   (d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the
       enclosure and PLC modules are cleaned of accumulated dust
       and debris.  [_ _]
11. Clean lighting diffusers (including emergency and Exit
    lighting) and lens of accumulated dust and debris.  [_ _]
12. Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for
    accumulated debris, evidence of water accumulation.   Record
    anything  abnormal in the Work Done area of the job
    sheet.   Record anything abnormal in the Work Done area of
    the Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader or his
    representative of outstanding actions.  [_ _]

Building (Control Panel) Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the control panel interior for evidence of moisture
   ingress.  Inspect for source of any water.  Record any
   details in the Work Done area of the job sheet and inform
   the Team Leader or his representative.  [_ _]
2. Check the doors and windows for damage, operation, lubricate
   and repair as required and record in the Work Done area
   of the Job Sheet.  Inform the Team Leader or his
   representative of any outstanding works.  [_ _]
3. Clean and remove by vacuuming, dust and debris from tops of
   cabinets, ledges, cable trays, cables, etc.
   Note: Dust will settle on all ledges and surfaces, e.g. Tops
   of cabinets, tops of cabinet doors, tops of meter escutcheons
   etc.  [_ _].
4. Clean exterior surfaces of cabinets where necessary.  [_ _]
5. Clean dust and cobwebs from interior walls, cabinets and
   ceilings.  [_ _]
6. Remove from site all accumulated rubbish and debris.  Empty
   rubbish bins and replace liners.  [_ _]
7. Sweep, vacuum and remove all accumulated dirt and dust from
   control panel interior.  [_ _]
8. Carry out Exterior Checks of control panel(s).
   (a) Visually inspect the exterior surfaces of the control
       panels for damage, erosion and graffiti.  [_ _]
   (b) Inspect (if applicable) the general area surrounding the
       control panel for erosion and damage to surfaces, fences,
       gates, pavements   [_ _]
9. Remove any accumulated debris from the surrounds.  [_ _]
10. Prior to leaving the site ensure:
   (a) All plant turned OFF has been returned to service e.g.
       pumps etc.  [_ _]
   (b) All Enclosures closed and locked.  [_ _]
   (c) All Lighting turned OFF  [_ _]
11. On completion of job record anything outside normal
    parameters
    e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
         leaks
         lighting faults
         door damage
     evidence of structural damage to the Pump Station and
     equipment etc,  in the Work Done  section of the job
     sheet and report to the Team Leader or his representative
     and raise a new job for any repairs.
12. Record any corrective action required, in the Work Done
    area of the job sheet.
13. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

9. Static Fan Checks for each fan.
   (a) Confirm that both the fan and motor are electrically and
mechanically isolated prior to
         commencing any work on the fan or the motor.
   (b) Enter the fan inlet cowl via the entry cowl safety grill hatch.
   (c) Examine the impeller for
         (i) Dirt and foreign matter on the blades (clean if required)
  [_ _]
         (ii) Wear or damage on the blade tips   [_ _]
         (ii) Wear or damage on the blade leading edges   [_ _]
         (iv) Loose bolts and or blade fixings at the hub   [_ _]
   (d) Examine the electrical cable for security of fixings, damage due
to fraying, scuffing or
         similar and for damage at locations where the cables penetrate
panels or
         housings.    [_ _]
   (e) Check any grease discharged from the motor bearings, since the
last lubrication is not
          excessive.   [_ _]
    (f ) Examine the discharged grease for any noticeable colour change.
Ensure that the
          grease nipples are clean.  [_ _]
   (g)  Inspect the cable connections to the motor for evidence of
overheating.  [_ _]
   (h) Carry out an insulation/resistance test of the motor and heater
windings.
          (i) Ensure fan motor is isolated.
          (ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
               Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has been
isolated and is to remain
               isolated.
               (a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and
                     bridge heater terminals.
               (b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
         (iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the motorwindings
and the
                winding heater bridge.  Record the result in the ""Work
Done"" area.
         (iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out
               an Insulation resistance test between this common bridge
and earth.  Record
               the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
        (v) Remove all temporary connections.
        (vi) Remove supply lines to the motor and carry out an
insulation resistance test
              on the motor windings, Between phase winding to phase
winding and between
              each phase winding and earth.  Record results in the Work
Done area of the
             Job sheet.
        (vii) If the heater was connected on arrival, then re-instate
the heater connections,
              otherwise leave the motor winding heater terminations
isolated.
        (viii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
        (x)  Where any insulation resistance reading is less than 2
megohm, then Record
                 in the ""Work Done""area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new job for the outstanding
                 works.  Include the Job Number of the new job in the
Related Job"" field as well
                 as in the alternate.  Notify the Team Leader or his
representative of any
                 outstanding works.
   (i) On leaving the fan inlet cowl grill hatch, replace the hatch
cover immediately.  [_ _]
   (j) Manually check the operation of the Rotork actuator and
associated linkages that
          operate the exit dampers, use the local control panel switch.

 [__]

    CAUTION:  ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS

     (a) When the Static Fan Checks are complete, return to substation

to the AUTO position.
     (c) Return to the ventilation room and have TCR start the fan,
thatis being maintained.
           Note: The motor must not be started more that four times in
an hour.
     (d) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan starts.
     (e) Lubricate the motor bearings with fresh grease, while the motor
running.
           DE = 100 gr / NDE - 120 gr  Use Shell Stamina RL2 grease or

using the retrieval

   operator's Manual . (Status Information 6.1.2 page 145)

   following;

       overheating.  [_ _]

       least each minute.  [_ _]

       interior.   [_ _]
5. Use laptop computer to carry out the following:

        controller input/output board.

       logger correctly.  [_ _]

       volts. [_ _]

      (computer screen) that all sensors, in each lane are

      alongside the appropriate loops as the truck crosses).

    (l) Select LOGGER/OFFLINE, then press Enter

    (n) Then select 'Quit' again, press Enter again.

1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
   during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995.  This
   standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
   and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
   lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
   place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
   this discharge test.   [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
   end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record on
   EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 4 AND ENVIRONS
  TMF-3012-OP-0246, only those fittings in which the tubes have been
replaced.
   FA - 2 x 36w tube
   FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
   FC - 1 x 18w tube
   EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
   EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
   EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
   EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
   EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
   EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
   EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
   EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
   EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for 90
   minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
   DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 4 AND ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0246,
   only those lights which does not provide suitable area
   lighting for the required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
   condition and then check that the battery charger operation
   indicator functions correctly.  Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
   DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 4 AND ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0246,
   only those light fittings that the battery charger operation
   indicator does not function correctly.
8. Clean all light emitting and reflecting surfaces of the
  emergency lights and exit signs. Record any broken or damaged
  diffusers on the form EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST -
  SUBSTATION 4 AND ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0246 for subsequent
  replacement.
9. Ensure the emergency lighting and exit signs operate in the
   correct relationship to the normal lighting.
10. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
    parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

At the photometer **COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. This job is to be carried out during a tunnel shut.
3. Clean the external surfaces, including glass window, of
   accumulated dirt and dust.  Use Rain-x and soft cloth.
4. Visually inspect the mounting components for damage,
   corrosion (Remove and repair any corrosion found) and
   security of fixings.
5. Visually check the cabling to the photometer for damage or
   any required repairs (Repairs as required).
6. Check the general alignment of the Photometer for accuracy.

Methodology for Alignment Check:

**The alignment point needs to be defined by taping the distance
betweenthe walls of the Tunnel entrance to identify the centre, then
taping from the pavement upto 1.5m above. The target needs to be
this point, taking into account that the laser beam would be generated
parallel to the centre of the photometer.

At the photometer, a laser level needs to be placed on top of the
photometer and the unit then needs to be adjusted until the beam hits
the target. The process must be repeated with the laser placed on each
side of the unit, meaning the adjustment on the target**

7. Record any outstanding works required.
8. Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding works.

ofany debris that may

      components.    [_ _]

correctly
      installed.    [_ _]

until new and clean

all expelled
     grease.   [_ _]

6.1 Measure the motor operating current flows for each phase, compare
with the rated

      components.    [_ _]

correctly
      installed.    [_ _]

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
2. Reference Manual, Fantech Pty Ltd. Olympic Park portal Centrifugal
Fans . Operations and
   Maintenance manual.  M STG-VE-26200.
   WARNING:
   HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN WHEN YOU ARE IN THE FAN
   ENCLOSURE.
3. Check fan outlet stacks and protective mesh for build up of debris
that will inhibit outlet
    damper operation use an extension ladder.  (3m wall) in accordance
with work instruction           TM1-3012-SA-0121 Ladders- Saf e inspect
and to clear any debris.  [_ _]
4. Static Fan checks
   Switch the fan AUTO/OFF/MANUAL switch to the OFF position, lock the
switch and tag, in
   accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103, before proceeding with the
inspection.
   (a) Check the safety guards and other safety features for safe
operating condition.  [_ _]
   (b) Check the flexible connection of the ducting  for leaks, tearing
and fraying.  [_ _]
   (c) Check the grease in the fan bearings for quality, apply Shell
Stamina RL2 (or equivalent)
         with a  grease gun if required. Greasing can be safely
performed with fan either static or
         running. Apply grease until new clean grease is exhausted from
the bearing.     [_ _]
   (d) Check the fan belts for wear and correct tension as per the O
&M Manual
         M-STG-VE-26200.    [_ _]
   (e) Check the belt pulley for wear and alignment.  Adjust if
required.   [_ _]
   (f ) Check that all fixings are secure.   [_ _]
   (g) Check for corrosion or deterioration in surface coatings.  [_ _]
   (h) Remove inspection covers and check fan internals for debris and
ingress of moisture.
         Clean if necessary.   [_ _]
5. Static Motor Checks.
    Lock out the motor controls at switchboard, and tag, in accordance
with TMI-3012-SA-0103.
    (a) Check that the motor is clear of accumulated dust on external
surfaces and that the
          external ventilation airways are clear. [_ _]
    (b) Carry out an insulation/resistance test of the motor and heater
windings.
          (i) Ensure fan motor is isolated.
          (ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
               Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has been
isolated and is to remain
               isolated.
               (a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and
                     bridge heater terminals.
               (b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
         (iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the motor
windings and the
                winding heater bridge.  Record the result in the ""Work
Done"" area.
         (iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out
               an Insulation resistance test between this common bridge
and earth.  Record
               the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
        (v) Remove all temporary connections.
        (vi) Remove supply lines to the motor and carry out an
insulation resistance test
              on the motor windings, Between phase winding to phase
winding and between
              each phase winding and earth.  Record results in the Work
Done area of the
             Job sheet.
        (vii) If the heater was connected on arrival, then re-instate
the heater connections,
              otherwise leave the motor winding heater terminations
isolated.
        (viii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
        (x)  Where any insulation resistance reading is less than 2
megohm, then Record
                 in the ""Work Done""area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new job for the outstanding
                 works.  Include the Job Number of the new job in the
Related Job"" field as well
                 as in the alternate.  Notify the Team Leader or his
representative of any
                 outstanding works.
           CAUTION:   DO NOT PERFORM AN INSULATION RESISTANCE TEST ON
                                  MOTOR THERMAL PROTECTION DEVICES
    (c) Check the motor starter, contacts and terminals where
          appropriate.   [_ _]
    (d) Check the lubrication of motor bearings and apply Shell Stamina
RL2 grease with a
           grease gun if required.    Greasing can be safely performed
with the motor either static
           or running.  Apply the grease until new clean grease is
extruded from the
           bearing.     [_ _]
6.  Fan Operation
    CAUTION:  ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED
                         AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.
    CAUTION:  DO NOT RUN MORE THAN 2 FANS AT ANY TIME.
    CAUTION:  A MINIMUM OF 4 INLET DAMPERS MUST BE OPEN BEFORE RUNNING
FANS.
    (a) Notify the control room to open the tunnel smoke inlet dampers.
    (b) Ensure all safety guards and inspection opening covers are in
place.  [_ _]
    (c) Remove tags and locks, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103,  andremove
the
          motor isolation.   [_ _]
    (d) Switch AUTO/OFF/MANUAL to MANUAL position and start each fan
using the
          START/STOP/RESET pushbutton. Run each fan for 30 minutes.
    (e) Check that the outlet damper opens fully.  [_ _]
           NOTE: The following checks shall be made using touch, sight
and hearing only.
                        Perceived problems will be referred for further
checks using instrumentation.
    (f ) Check the fan bearings for uneven rumbling or hammering noise.
 [_ _]
    (g) Check fan bearings for overheating by holding hand on bearing
for 5 -10seconds.  [_ _]
    (h) Check fans for excessive vibration (surging or beating sound)
orshuddering on start
          up or run down.   [_ _]
    (i) Check the ducting  flexible connections are not overstressed due
to fan movement.  [_ _]
    (j) Check that the seismic mounts have free movement and are secure.
 [_ _]
7. Motor checks
   (a) Check the motor for noisy running and excessive vibration.  [_ _]
   (b) Check for excessive heating by holding hand on motor in bearing
areas for 5-10
           seconds.   [_ _]
   (c) Measure and compare the motor current with the rated current.
  FLC 125A
8. (a) On completion of checks switch the fan OFF using the
START/STOP/RESET pushbutton.
   (b) Check that the outlet damper closes fully on shutdown.   [_ _]
   (c) Request the control room to close inlet smoke dampers.  [_ _]
9. Reset the fan AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the AUTO position.
 [_ _]
10. Ensure the fan station is clean and all accumulated debris and
rubbish is removed.  [_ _]
11. Record any corrective action required, in the ""Work Done"" area of
the job sheet.  [_ _]
12. On completion of the job notify the control room.  [_ _]

            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	At the photometer **COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	2. This job is to be carried out during a tunnel shut.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	3. Clean the external surfaces, including glass window, of
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   accumulated dirt and dust.  Use Rain-x and soft cloth.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	4. Visually inspect the mounting components for damage,
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   corrosion (Remove and repair any corrosion found) and
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   security of fixings.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	5. Visually check the cabling to the photometer for damage or
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	   any required repairs (Repairs as required).
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	6. Check the general alignment of the Photometer for accuracy.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	Methodology for Alignment Check:
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	**The alignment point needs to be defined by taping the distance
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	betweenthe walls of the Tunnel entrance to identify the centre, then
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	taping from the pavement upto 1.5m above. The target needs to be
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	this point, taking into account that the laser beam would be generated
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	parallel to the centre of the photometer.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	At the photometer, a laser level needs to be placed on top of the
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	photometer and the unit then needs to be adjusted until the beam hits
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	the target. The process must be repeated with the laser placed on each
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	side of the unit, meaning the adjustment on the target**
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	7. Record any outstanding works required.
            	                                        	                	                                        	 	        	  	8. Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding works.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

A Job Start as a minimum must be completed in consultation with
all participating employees to identify, assess and control the
hazards prior to work commencing.
The job start should take into account the following hazards as a
minimum:
           Traffic
           Manual Handling
           Sharps & other foreign objects
           Slips, Trips & Falls
           Noise
           UV radiation
           Inclement weather
Other hazards particular to the location or conditions should be
identified, assessed, controlled and noted on the Job Start form prior
to the work commencing.

1. Inspect and clean the Road Reserve surface and sub-surface
   drainage system as per
   Work Instruction TMI-3012-OP-0009, in the following WL
   sectors:
   S5/N3 Tollway Flemington Road to Dynon Road
   S6/N2 Tollway Dynon Road to Footscray Road and
   S7/N1 Tollway Footscray Road to West Gate Freeway
2. Keys to perimeter gates maybe required.
3. Notify control room prior to commencing work.
4. Use flashing amber beacon light on vehicles and wear
   fluorescent vest when on foot.
5. Clean surface drainage of any form of debris (Kerb & channel,
   spoon drains).
6. Clean pits and culverts of debris and blockages that have
   built up debris.
7. Check pits and culverts for structural damage including
   covers, lintels and surrounds.
8. Check pipes and inspection elbow caps within the viaduct
   section of the elevated road for damage and missing caps.
9. Whilst in right lane closures on the Elevated Road, check all
   Emergency pedestrian bridges that connect the two seperate
   carriageways. Assemble the bridge handrails, checking for
   correct operation and for safety functions. Lubricate all
   hinged joints and disassemble to stored position. Ensure
   that moveable parts are secured with their lanyards and
   shackles.
10. All cleaning activities and further maintenance requirements
   to be recorded on check sheet TMF-3012-OP-0008

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

1.  Carry out the three monthly planned maintenance defined
    in the CML RSE
       Users Manual maintenance schedule, document no.
       M-MCL-ET-1225.
2.  Perimeter access gate at technical shelter key required.
3.  Use caution when working above traffic, ensure equipment
    and or tools do not fall from the gantry.  Only essential
    equipment is to be taken onto the Gantry.  Adhere to safety
    instructions TMI-3012-SA-0101 "Working on Gantry
    Structures".
4.  Notify Control Room prior to accessing the Gantry.
5.  Complete CML RSE Maintenance Plan PL-MCL-ET-100001.
     Preventative Maintenance No.
      0302: Clean external glass of the sensors and inspect
            mounting brackets, lubricate as required.
            Ensure pins are cleaned and lubricated using silicon
            spray prior to installing.
      0303: Check VR Illuminators that there are Less than 10%' ,,,,,,
defective IR LED's, Advice CML if suspect below 10%
            NOTE: [USE THE INFRA-RED VIEWING SCOPE (300000891)
            IN LOCATION A1303]
      0305: Lamp cover on poles and grantry cleaned.
      0306: Road Markers: Inspect for clarity & Cleanliness.
                High contrast between marker & road). (If road ,,
,,,,    markers need to be changed, inform the Team Leader.)
,,  0308: Inspect Distribution Cabinet for loose or damaged ,,,,,,
   cables. Clean cabinet for insects or moisture.

6.  Record in the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet any
    outstanding works requiring further
    attention.  Create a new Job sheet for any outstanding works
    and notify the Team Leader or his representative of the
    outstanding works.  Record the New job number in the "Work
    Done" area of this job sheet and in the "Related Job" field
    of both jobs.
7. Notify Control Room prior to departing from the Technical
    Shelter.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this Job.
2. Inspect and check access gates as set out on the form
   TMF-3012-OP-0308  SL Gate Inspection.
3. At each gate:
    (a) Check the gate for damage
    (b) Unlock the gate and check for operation
    (b) Check the gate hinges for fixings and operation
    (c) Check the gate locking method for security and correct
        lock.
    (d) Check the area for accumulated debris and graffiti.
    (e) Visually check the pavement (where fitted) for damage
    (f)  Using a Graphite dust puffer, apply Graphite dust to
         key entry and to shackle entries, then exercise lock
         and key to distribute Graphite dust.
   (g)  Replace missing or damaged locks as required.  Lock to
        be issued by Translink Operations Traffic Control room
4.  For each gate, record the result of the inspections on the
    form SL Gate Inspection - TMF-3012-OP-0308.
5. Notify control room when inspection is complete.
6. Ensure the completed job sheets and the form  SL Gate and
   Fence Inspection - TMF-3012-OP-0308 is returned to the Civil
   Team Leader or his representative.
7. The Civil Team Leader or his representative is to raise a new
   jobsheet for any outstanding works that requires further
   attention.

1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the work.
2. Use Vehicle arrow board and short term emergency lane
   stoppage as per Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 13
   or 14.
3. For northbound carriageway and at each emergency roadside
   telephone:
   (a) Inspect the telephone for graffiti, damage and or insect
       infestation
   (b) Clean the telephone of grime and residues, use spray-on
       Nifty and a clean cloth.
   (c) Test the operation of the telephone with the control
       room.  Using the Emergency Roadside telephone, contact
       the Traffic Control Room and confirm operation of the
       phone communication then have the control room call back
       to the ERT to check the reverse operation.
4. For southbound carriageway and at each emergency roadside
   telephone:
   (a) Inspect the telephone for graffiti, damage and or insect
       infestation
   (b) Clean the telephone of grime and residues, use spray-on
       Nifty and a clean cloth.
   (c) Test the operation of the telephone with the control
       room.  Using the Emergency Roadside telephone, contact
       the Traffic Control Room and confirm operation of the
       phone communication then have the control room call back
       to the ERT to check the reverse operation.
5. For each ERT
   (a) record the result of the inspection
   (b) that the ERT has been cleaned and
   (c) the result of the communication test
   for each telephone on the attached form METS Inspection
   (Monthly) - Western Link Form No. TMF-3012-OP-0036.
6. Record the details of any further corrective actions that are
   required in the comments area of the form.
7. Notify the control room on the completion of inspection.
8. Return the completed job sheet as well as the form METS
   Inspection (Monthly) - Western Link Form No. TMF-3012-OP-0036
   to the Electrical / Electronics Team Leader or his
   representative.
9. The Electrical / Electronics Team Leader or his
   representative is to raise a new job sheet for any corrective
   actions required.
